title: Mental Health Solutions: Ayurveda Treats the Whole Mind-Body Complex
description: Looking for a holistic approach to mental health? Ayurveda treats the whole mind-body complex. Read on to learn how you can improve your wellbeing.
cleaned_text: By Anuradha Gupta | Posted : November 06, 2020 Looking for a holistic approach to mental health? Ayurveda treats the whole mind-body complex. Read on to learn how you can improve your wellbeing. Grief, loneliness, [anxiety,](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/feeling-insecure-you-can-use-these-6-anxiety-tips-for-your-fears) depression, insomnia, substance abuse, and [suicidal thoughts](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/world-suicide-prevention-global-panel-discusses-the-need-of-the-times). All these are either a result of severe stressors or in themselves can cause severe stress. The [Covid-19 pandemic](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2771763) has increased [stress levels](https://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2020/10/stress-mental-health-crisis) greatly. A June [CDC survey](https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/13/health/mental-health-coronavirus-pandemic-cdc-study-wellness/index.html) found that a staggering 41% of US respondents reported at least one mental or behavioral health condition during the pandemic. Those with increased risk to mental health challenges include caregivers, essential workers, the [young](https://medicalxpress.com/news/2020-10-stress-america-survey-reveals-mental.html), elderly, minorities, people with pre-existing health conditions, and those with [multiple hardships](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/09/200902182417.htm). This winter brings added worries about flu season, [allergies](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/can-ayurveda-help-with-autumn-allergies-say-bye-bye-to-your-sniffles), and a third (?) wave. [Quarantine fatigue](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/quarantine-fatigue-is-real-these-6-ways-can-help-you-cope-with-it), loneliness, and Seasonal Affective Disorder ( [SAD](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/feeling-sad-5-natural-remedies-for-seasonal-affective-disorder)) further compromise our mental wellbeing. What mental health suggestions does the 5,000-year-old Science of Ayurveda offer? How Ayurveda Views Mental Health Ayurveda defines health as a balance of energy principles ( [Doshas](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/balancing-your-health-and-dosha-types)) and a pleasant state of mind. It is holistic and acknowledges the mind-body-spirit connection. Every Ayurvedic intake includes an assessment of psychological factors, lifestyle, and current stressors. Mental imbalances (Manovikara) are cared for as part of the disease process and aren't stigmatized. Our Ayurvedic constitution is composed of three Doshas and their imbalances cause diseases. [Vata](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-to-balance-vata-dosha-9-tips-for-balancing-your-body-and-mind) imbalance typically causes anxiety and phobias, [Pitta](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/7-tips-for-balance-and-health-of-the-pitta-dosha), anger, and obsessions, and [Kapha](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/understanding-kapha-dosha-a-few-tips-to-balance-your-body-and-mind) could cause depression. Likewise, we all go through phases of feeling uplifted, restless, or lethargic. These are attributes of the mind (Gunas). Sattva is the natural state of the mind that we try to attain for optimal mental health. It is light, productive, and balanced. Rajas is ambitious and restless and Tamas is lethargic and dull. While we need Rajas and Tamas to work or rest, their imbalance can cause anger or depression. Mental health imbalances are also caused by genetic and external factors, the effect of time, a misuse of our senses or knowingly doing something that harms the health like overeating or engaging in a violent argument! Raising Prana (vital life force) and awareness through practices like meditation helps us to make better lifestyle choices. Ayurvedic Mental Health Management Let's consider simplified examples, Case 1: Elliot is 15, with an anxiety diagnosis, fear of the dark, disturbed sleep, traveling aches and pains, and allergies. Based on a comprehensive assessment, his case is managed through classical Vata balancing. Case 2: Astha is a 27-year-old techie with anger issues that have cost her a job. She is ambitious, intellectual, restless, and overindulges in spicy food, drinking, and late nights despite suffering from hyperacidity. In her case, we try to manage Pitta imbalance and reduce Rajas by raising Sattva. Case 3: Sue is 49 with Type II bipolar disorder. She is very stable but has menopausal mood swings. We make sure she stays on her medication. In a standard assessment, we find issues with [Agni,](https://artoflivingretreatcenter.org/blog/understanding-the-agni-principle/) Vata-Pitta imbalance, a tendency to burn out, and attend to impacted channels in an integrative approach. Classical disease management in psychiatric ailments (Unmada) includes Spiritual Therapy (chants, [mantras](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/living-forward/201906/mantra-powerful-way-improve-your-well-being), and gem therapy), Psycho-behavioral, and Biological Therapies with Palliation (through herbs, [nutrition](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-the-ayurvedic-diet-transforms-your-body), lifestyle changes) and [cleansing](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/this-ayurveda-fall-cleanse-will-get-your-body-in-shape-for-the-season). Ayurvedic Tips to enhance Mental Health 1. Increase Sattva a. [Yoga](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/a-true-tale-how-yoga-can-help-build-self-confidence-and-mental-health) and [breathwork](https://event.us.artofliving.org/us-en/research/)- Harvard Medical School has [recommended yoga](https://www.theweek.in/news/world/2020/03/16/harvard-medical-school-recommends-yoga-to-deal-with-covid-19-anxiety.html) to deal with Covid-19 anxiety and depression. Read more about the [benefits](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/yoga/yoga-benefits/top-ten-yoga-benefits) of yoga and [yoga poses](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/when-you-feel-blue-try-these-7-yoga-poses-for-anxiety-and-depression) for better mental health. [Here's](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/yoga/breathing-techniques/yoga-and-pranayama) a beginner's guide to [breathing exercises](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/learn-pranayama-breath-control-and-its-positive-effects-on-your-health) and techniques [Meditation](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/how-meditation-changes-your-brain) rewires your is a natural mode of [Vagus Nerve Stimulation](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/the-vagus-nerve-and-the-healing-promise-of-Sudarshan-Kriya) leading to many health benefits. In a recent groundbreaking [Yale meditation research](https://news.yale.edu/2020/07/27/improve-students-mental-health-yale-study-finds-teach-them-breathe), it was found to be more effective than mindfulness or cognitive approaches for well-being, anxiety, depression, and social connections for students. c. Sattvik food: Have natural, fresh, not overly spiced, easy to digest, light food with plenty of fruits and vegetables. Favor whole grains and lentils and avoid processed, junk food, white sugar, and white flour. d. [Volunteering](https://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/how_volunteering_can_help_your_mental_health): Uplifting others and volunteering can reduce stress and help create a support system. e. Sadvrutta: Positive practices that alter our cognitive frameworks like self-inquiry, [patience](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/patience-is-a-virtue-how-you-can-easily-wait-for-the-lockdown-to-end), a healthy routine, regular exercise, and [meditation](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/meditation/meditation-for-you/benefits-of-meditation). These [nurture resilience](https://www.psychologytoday.com/intl/blog/nurturing-resilience/202010/the-upside-the-pandemic-is-there-one) (as also cultivating hobbies, [creativity](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/pranayama-breathing-can-spark-your-creative-fire-try-these-4-today), and [gratitude](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/mindful-anger/201807/science-proves-gratitude-is-key-well-being) journaling). 2. Preventive health and restoring balance a. Three pillars - The foundations of good health include a [nutritious diet](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-the-ayurvedic-diet-transforms-your-body) ( [nutritional psychiatry](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/nutritional-psychiatry-your-brain-on-food-201511168626) is the and a balanced lifestyle. [The Gut-Brain](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/wellness-and-prevention/the-brain-gut-connection) axis is a new frontier in neuroscience acknowledging the link between mental health and gut microbiota. In Ayurveda managing digestive and metabolic fire is the starting point to attain Dosha balance for mental and physical health. b. Follow a Seasonal and [Daily regimen](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/ayurveda-dinacharya-circadian-rhythm-of-your-body-for-optimal-wellness): Align with natural rhythms; fall could be an anxious time with [Vata](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-to-balance-vata-dosha-9-tips-for-balancing-your-body-and-mind) imbalance and winter, with [Kapha](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/understanding-kapha-dosha-a-few-tips-to-balance-your-body-and-mind)-related depression. [Here are some tips ](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/transition-well-to-winter-months-with-these-tips-by-an-ayurveda-expert)on balancing these Doshas in the winter. c. Herbs - Consult an Ayurvedic Practitioner before taking herbs. Medhya Rasayana or brain tonics inherently boost Nasya (oil or herb application in the nostrils), or therapies like Shirodhara (pouring of warm medicated oil on the forehead) and a full [Panchakarma](https://artoflivingretreatcenter.org/ayurveda/panchakarma/) (a comprehensive, individualized therapeutic cleanse). e. Boosting immunity - Boosting immunity through Ayurveda, [yoga](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/yoga/health-and-wellness/yoga-natural-immunity-booster), and [meditation](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/meditation-and-immunity-what-you-wished-you-known-years-ago) increases mental resilience. Try [this](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/yoga-video-to-boost-your-body-is-lymphatic-system-drainage-and-immunity) yoga sequence for lymphatic drainage ( [video](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/yoga-video-to-boost-your-body-is-lymphatic-system-drainage-and-immunity) included). 3. Soothe the senses through [pratyahara](https://artoflivingretreatcenter.org/blog/pratyahara-yogas-forgotten-limb/) (sensory withdrawal) and avoid negativity and [digital overload](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/your-brain-is-experiencing-an-information-overload-ayurveda-can-help). Practice [eyecare](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/yoga/health-and-wellness/yoga-eyes), color therapy, aromatherapy, try soothing music, [tongue-cleaning](https://artoflivingretreatcenter.org/blog/ayurveda-101-the-benefits-of-tongue-scraping/), oil pulling, and have nourishing food. 4. Nurture relationships - Attend to social health, keep [socially connected](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/how-to-maintain-social-connection-in-the-time-of-coronavirus) while distanced. Ayurvedic scholar, [Dr. David Frawley](https://www.organiser.org/Encyc/2020/3/4/Prevention-for-Coronavirus.html), attributes the decline in our collective physical and psychological immunity to losing our connection with nature and the ability to withstand stress. This is also a time to heal our relationship with nature and [commit to sustainability](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-to-save-the-planet-while-it-is-still-not-too-late-start-at-home). [Mental Health Management during Pandemics](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0975947620300644) For prevention, management, and recovery from illness, lifestyle modifications like yoga and meditation are recommended for everyone. In addition to these principles, a recent review of Ayurveda and [mental health during Covid-19](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Bhushan_Raghuwanshi/publication/343878885_A_REVIEW_STUDY_ON_MENTAL_HEALTH_-THE_ROLE_OF_DIFFERENT_PERSPECTIVES_OF_AYURVEDA_DURING_COVID-19_PANDEMIC/links/5f461bb8458515b72956f82b) advocated [SKY Breath Meditation](https://event.us.artofliving.org/us-en/research/) and [yoga effective tools. of the pandemic, Gurudev Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, founder of Art of Living asked us to care for those who've lost loved ones, attend to immunity, and meditate often. He also reassured us that this shall pass. If you have suffered a loss of a loved one you may have a [ Vata imbalance](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/how-to-balance-vata-dosha-9-tips-for-balancing-your-body-and-mind) caused by grief. You can help your healing through grounding practices like [Abhyanga](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/abhyanga-the-benefits-of-adding-ayurveda-self-massage-to-your-self-love-routine) and [abdominal breathing](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/yoga/breathing-techniques), unctuous nutrition, and staying warm. Do consider grief counseling as well. Don't hesitate to seek [professional help](https://www.nami.org/Your-Journey/Individuals-with-Mental-Illness/Finding-a-Mental-Health-Professional) or call or text a [crisis helpline](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/managing-stress-anxiety.html) if you're depressed, anxious, or feel suicidal. The Art of Living Foundation is also offering support if you need to talk during these challenging times. [Lend an Ear](https://event.us.artofliving.org/us-en/need-to-talk/) volunteers can be reached at 855-998-3899, 7 pm to 9 pm PST. While the pandemic's [mental health impact](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/hsph-in-the-news/covid-19-pandemic-may-cause-long-term-mental-health-issues/) could linger, we can also [grow in resilience](https://rightasrain.uwmedicine.org/mind/mental-health/resilience-after-pandemic). The pandemic has reminded us how precious life is; let's focus on [self-care](https://bit.ly/34CSaop) and remember, we're together in this. Ayurveda recommends [meditation for immunity](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/blog/meditation-and-immunity-what-you-wished-you-known-years-ago) and [mental health](https://www.artofliving.org/us-en/here-is-what-the-latest-studies-say-about-meditation-and-mental-health).
